questions.text: 38 weeks primi in early labour with the transverse presentation, how will you manage her:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

LSCS The onset of active labour in a woman with a transverse lie is an indication of cesarean delivery.

Highyeild:

Once labour is well-established, attempts at conversion to a longitudinal lie by abdominal manipulation are likely to be unsuccessful. Before labour or early in labour, with the membranes intact, attempts at an external version are worth trying in the absence of other complications that indicate cesarean section. When a patient with a transverse lie is seen in labour, it is managed as follows: Early labour: ECV – provided there is a good amount of liquor amnii and there is no contraindication. ECV should be tried in all cases. LSCS – is the preferred method of delivery, if the version fails or is contraindicated. Late labour: Baby alive – If the baby is mature and the fetal condition is good , it is preferable to do LSCS in all cases. Baby dead – LSCS. The internal version should not be done. In transverse lie – the presentation is shoulder presentation.

Extraedge:

M/C cause of transverse lie is prematurity. M/C cause of transverse lie in term pregnancy – placenta previa. There is no mechanism of labour in transverse lie. M/C cause of cord prolapse is a transverse lie. Hand prolapse occurs in transverse lie. Management of transverse lie with live baby in labour – caesarean section. Management of transverse lie with dead baby – caesarean section. Management of neglected shoulder presentation – caesarean section. Management of transverse lie during pregnancy – external cephalic version. Management of 1st twins with a transverse lie – caesarean section. Management of 2nd twin with a transverse lie – Internal Podalic Version.

questions.text: A deep transverse arrest is seen in all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transverse lie The deep transverse arrest is a complication of occipitoposterior position. In a transverse lie, the presenting part is the shoulder, so no question of DTA of the head.

Highyeild:

Causes of deep transverse arrest: Faulty pelvic architecture – android pelvis Depression of the head Weak uterine contractions Laxity of pelvic floor muscles Epidural analgesia causes a prolonged 2nd stage of labour.

questions.text: In which fetal presentation vaginal delivery can be expected?

options.label: A
options.text: Face presentation when the chin lies directly to the sacrum

options.label: D
options.text: Face presentation when the chin lies under the symphysis pubis

questions.correct_answer: D. Face presentation when the chin lies under the symphysis pubis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Face presentation when the chin lies under the symphysis pubis

Highyeild:

Face presentation: The attitude of the fetus shows complete flexion of the limbs with the extension of the spine. There is a complete extension of the head so that the occiput is in contact with the back. The denominator is mentum. The commonest position is left mentoanterior (LMA). Face presentation present during pregnancy (primary) is rare, while that developing after the onset of labour (secondary) is common. It occurs more frequently seen in multiparae (70%), like other malpresentation. The most common maternal cause is platypelloid pelvis and the most common fetal cause is anencephaly. The diameter of engagement is the oblique diameter —right in LMA, left in RMA. The engaging diameter of the head is submento-bregmatic 9.5 cm in the fully extended head or submentovertical 11.5 cm in the partially extended head. Engagement is delayed because of the long distance between the mentum and biparietal plane (7 cm). The head is born by flexion: (11.5 cm). Vaginal delivery is possible in mentoanterior positions but not in persistent mentoposterior. In mentoposterior during the early stages of labour, the policy of wait and watch should be adopted, in the hope of mentoposterior getting converted to mentoanterior spontaneously. Persistent mentoposterior position is an indication for doing a cesarean section.

options.label: C
options.text: A woman presenting with a life-threatening condition but has survived

options.label: D
options.text: A woman presenting with a life-threatening condition who has died

questions.correct_answer: C. A woman presenting with a life-threatening condition but has survived
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A woman presenting with a life-threatening condition but has survived

Highyeild:

A woman presenting with any life-threatening condition and surviving is considered a Maternal Near Miss case. Maternal Near Miss is a retrospective event . From the definition point of view, a woman can only be recognized as a maternal near miss, when she survives the severe complications in pregnancy, labour or postpartum six weeks.

questions.text: On the external cephalic version, fetal bradycardia occurred. The next course of action is:

options.label: A
options.text: Reversion to the original position immediately by external version

questions.correct_answer: A. Reversion to the original position immediately by external version
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reversion to the original position immediately by external version

Highyeild:

External cephalic version: Is done to bring a favourable cephalic pole in the lower pole of the uterus. Indications: Breech presentation Transverse lie Procedure: The maneuver is carried out after 35 weeks under the effect of Terbutaline 0.25 mg s.c . or Isoxsuprine 50–100 μg IV. Ultrasound examination is done to confirm the diagnosis and adequacy of amniotic fluid volume. A reactive NST should precede the maneuver. Then ECV is attempted followed by a repeat NST after the procedure. There may be undue bradycardia due to head compression which is expected to settle down by 10 minutes. If however, fetal bradycardia persists , the possibility of cord entanglement should be kept in mind and in such cases, reversion is done. If the version is successful the patient is observed for 30 minutes: To allow for the fetal heart rate to settle down to normal. If even after reversion, fetal distress persists—a cesarean should be done.

questions.text: The following are related to face presentations except:

options.label: C
options.text: The diameter distending the vulval outlet is mento vertical

options.label: D
options.text: During moulding, there is the elongation of the occipitofrontal diameter

questions.correct_answer: C. The diameter distending the vulval outlet is mento vertical
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The diameter distending the vulval outlet is mento vertical

Highyeild:

Face presentation: The attitude of the fetus shows complete flexion of the limbs with the extension of the spine.
